Comments System â€“ Usage Patterns

Different ways toÂ import andÂ use theÂ comments system alongside StandardÂ Framework.

Pattern 1: Comments OnlyÂ (Standalone)

Use justÂ theÂ comments system without otherÂ Standard FrameworkÂ features.

//Â eleventy.config.js
import CommentsPlugin from â€œ@zefish/standard/src/cloudflare/comments-plugin.jsâ€;

export default function (eleventyConfig) {
  eleventyConfig.addPlugin(CommentsPlugin, {
    outputDir: â€œfunctions/apiâ€,
    copyClientLibrary: true,
  });
}

UseÂ Case: You want comments butÂ donâ€™t need typography, grid, orÂ otherÂ StandardÂ features.

Result:

  • âœ… Comments handler copied toÂ functions/api/comments.js
  • âœ… Client library copied toÂ assets/js/standard.comment.js
  • âœ… Configuration templateÂ copied

Pattern 2: Standard + Comments Together

Use bothÂ theÂ main Standard Framework andÂ commentsÂ system.

//Â eleventy.config.js
import Standard from â€œ@zefish/standardâ€;
import CommentsPlugin from â€œ@zefish/standard/src/cloudflare/comments-plugin.jsâ€;

export default function (eleventyConfig) {
  // Main framework (typography, grid, CSS,Â JS)
  eleventyConfig.addPlugin(Standard, {
    outputDir: â€œassets/standardâ€,
    copyFiles: true,
  });

  // Comments system (separateÂ endpoint)
  eleventyConfig.addPlugin(CommentsPlugin, {
    outputDir: â€œfunctions/apiâ€,
    copyClientLibrary: true,
  });
}

UseÂ Case: You want typography + comments. Perfect forÂ blogs.

Result:

  • âœ… Standard CSS/JS inÂ assets/standard/
  • âœ… Comments handler inÂ functions/api/comments.js
  • âœ… Comments client inÂ assets/js/standard.comment.js
  • âœ… BothÂ plugins workÂ independently

Pattern 3: Standard + Comments + Custom Cloudflare Functions

Use Standard Framework, comments, plus your ownÂ customÂ functions.

//Â eleventy.config.js

import CloudflarePlugin from â€œ@zefish/standard/src/eleventy/cloudflare.jsâ€;

export default function (eleventyConfig) {
  // MainÂ framework
  eleventyConfig.addPlugin(Standard);

  // AllÂ Cloudflare functions (copies entire src/cloudflare/Â directory)
  eleventyConfig.addPlugin(CloudflarePlugin, {
    outputDir: â€œfunctionsâ€,
    environment: â€œproductionâ€,
  });

  // Comments as separate plugin forÂ finerÂ control
  eleventyConfig.addPlugin(CommentsPlugin, {
    outputDir: â€œfunctions/apiâ€,
    copyClientLibrary: true,
  });
}

UseÂ Case: You need comments + your ownÂ serverlessÂ functions.

Result:

  • âœ… AllÂ functions inÂ functions/
  • âœ… Comments handler inÂ functions/api/comments.js
  • âœ… Your custom functions inÂ functions/ asÂ well
  • âœ… Full control over CloudflareÂ setup

Pattern 4: Conditional Comments (Feature Flag)

Enable/disable comments based onÂ environment.

//Â eleventy.config.js
import Standard from â€œ@zefish/standardâ€;
import CommentsPlugin from â€œ@zefish/standard/src/cloudflare/comments-plugin.jsâ€;

export default function (eleventyConfig) {
  eleventyConfig.addPlugin(Standard);

  // OnlyÂ add comments inÂ production
  if (process.env.ELEVENTY_ENV === â€œproductionâ€) {
    eleventyConfig.addPlugin(CommentsPlugin, {
      outputDir: â€œfunctions/apiâ€,
    });
  } else {
    console.log(â€œ[Comments] Disabled inÂ developmentâ€);
  }
}

UseÂ Case: Comments onlyÂ onÂ production, not onÂ dev/staging.

Result:

  • âœ… Comments onlyÂ deployed toÂ production
  • âœ… Dev/staging builds skip commentsÂ overhead
  • âœ… Easy toÂ toggleÂ on/off

Pattern 5: Comments + Multiple Cloudflare Endpoints

  eleventyConfig.addPlugin(Standard);

  // CommentsÂ system
  eleventyConfig.addPlugin(CommentsPlugin, {
    outputDir: â€œfunctions/apiâ€,
    copyClientLibrary: true,
  });

  // Your custom functions inÂ separateÂ directory
  eleventyConfig.addPassthroughCopy({
    â€œsrc/functions/**/*.jsâ€: â€œfunctions/â€,
  });
}

FileÂ Structure:

functions/
â”œâ”€â”€ api/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ comments.js     (from CommentsPlugin)
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ utils.js        (from CommentsPlugin)
â”œâ”€â”€ auth.js             (your custom)
â”œâ”€â”€ analytics.js        (your custom)
â””â”€â”€ webhook.js          (your custom)

Pattern 7: Custom Comments Endpoint Handler

Create your ownÂ comments handler while reusing theÂ clientÂ library.

//Â eleventy.config.js

import CommentsPlugin from â€œ@zefish/standard/src/cloudflare/comments-plugin.jsâ€;

export default function (eleventyConfig) {
  eleventyConfig.addPlugin(Standard);

  // OnlyÂ copy client library, not theÂ handler
  eleventyConfig.addPlugin(CommentsPlugin, {
    outputDir: â€œfunctions/apiâ€,
    copyClientLibrary: true,
    // TheseÂ wouldÂ require exposing asÂ options:
    // copyHandler:Â false,
    // copyConfig:Â false,
  });

  // Use your ownÂ handler
  eleventyConfig.addPassthroughCopy({
    â€œsrc/my-comments-handler.jsâ€: â€œfunctions/api/comments.jsâ€,
  });
}

UseÂ Case: You want toÂ customize theÂ comments handlerÂ behavior.

Result:

  • âœ… Use standard clientÂ library
  • âœ… Custom server-sideÂ logic
  • âœ… Full control over validation/spamÂ detection

Import Reference

Main Framework

Cloudflare Plugin (allÂ functions)

Comments Plugin (comments only)

import CommentsPlugin from â€œ@zefish/standard/src/cloudflare/comments-plugin.jsâ€;

Direct Imports (forÂ custom setup)

// BrowserÂ library

//Â Utilities

Configuration Examples

Production Setup

export default function (eleventyConfig) {
  eleventyConfig.addPlugin(Standard);

  eleventyConfig.addPlugin(CommentsPlugin, {
    outputDir: â€œfunctions/apiâ€,
    copyClientLibrary: true,
    copyTemplate: false, // Donâ€™t need template inÂ production
  });
}

Development Setup

export default function (eleventyConfig) {
  eleventyConfig.addPlugin(Standard);

  if (process.env.ELEVENTY_ENV === â€œproductionâ€) {
    eleventyConfig.addPlugin(CommentsPlugin);
  }
}

Monorepo Setup (multiple sites)

export default function (eleventyConfig) {
  const siteType = process.env.SITE_TYPE || â€œblogâ€;

  // Always include baseÂ framework
  eleventyConfig.addPlugin(Standard);

  // Conditionally addÂ comments
  if (siteType === â€œblogâ€ || siteType === â€œfullâ€) {
    eleventyConfig.addPlugin(CommentsPlugin);
  }
}

Troubleshooting

Q: CanÂ I use Standard andÂ CommentsÂ together? A: Yes! Use Pattern 2. Theyâ€™re designed toÂ workÂ together.

Q: DoÂ I need Standard forÂ comments? A: No! Use Pattern 1. Comments workÂ standalone.

Q: HowÂ doÂ I add customÂ functions? A: Use Pattern 5. Copy your functions toÂ aÂ separateÂ directory.

Q: CanÂ I disable comments inÂ development? A: Yes! Use Pattern 4 withÂ environmentÂ checks.

Q: HowÂ doÂ I use justÂ theÂ clientÂ library? A: Import directly: import GitHubComments fromÂ â€œ@zefish/standard/src/cloudflare/standard.comment.jsâ€
